filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive are pleased to announce the publication of three new electronic editions of Blake's most popular work, Songs of Innocence and of Experience. They are of Copies C, F, and L—none has been reproduced before now.
Songs Copy C is one of the first copies of the combined Songs. Along with Copies B, D, and E, it was formed in 1794 of Innocence plates printed in raw sienna on both sides of the leaf in 1789 and Experience plates lightly color printed in yellow ochre in the same format in 1794. By this time, Blake had decided to move Plates 34-36 ("The Little Girl Lost" and "The Little Girl Found") to Experience, but since Plate 34 was printed on the verso of the leaf with Plate 26 ("A Dream"), Plate 26 is read in this copy, as well as in Copies B and D, as an Experience poem. And, like Copies B and D, Copy C is missing Plate 52 ("To Tirzah") but has the small vignette known as plate a (five cherubs carrying a naked figure), one of Blake's earliest relief etchings used here as a tailpiece. Copy C is in the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress.
Bibliographically, Copy F is even more interesting. It, too, consists of two sections printed differently and at different times. Its Innocence plates were printed in green ink on both sides of the leaf in 1789, probably before the raw sienna printing. Its Experience plates were heavily color printed on one side of the leaf in 1794, before those in Copy C, possibly while Experience was still in progress. The impressions of Experience were printed with those now in Songs Copies G, H, and T, which are all missing Plates 39, 44, 45, and 48. Together, these four plates form one sheet of copper. The fact that all four plates are missing from all four copies suggests that the plates were not yet part of Experience at the time of this printing. These four color-printed copies of Experience appear to have been intended as autonomous publications. At any rate, there are no extant sets of Innocence impressions printed in this style, Copies G and H remain without Innocence, and Copies F and T were assembled by someone other than Blake.
Songs Copy L, like Copy F, is in the Yale Center for British Art. Unlike Copies C and F, though, its two parts were printed together in a uniform style, dark brown ink on one side of the leaf, ca. 1795. It has all 54 plates, including Plate 52, that make up the combined Songs and is numbered by Blake 1-54.
All of these editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and all are fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates. We now have twenty-nine copies of sixteen illuminated books in the Archive. We will soon be adding two more copies of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell and an in-depth illustrated Tour highlighting the Archive's features and some ways to use its resources. We will continue to add new electronic editions of illuminated books throughout the spring and summer.

imprint.publisher: William Blake Blake's name is given as the "printer" on the title pages to *Songs of Innocence* and *Songs of Experience*, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not printed in the book, but Blake lived in London and its suburb, Lambeth, during the composition, etching, and printing of the work.
imprint.date: 1789, 1794 The 1789 imprint appears on the title page to *Songs of Innocence*, the 1794 imprint on the title page to *Songs of Experience*.

objinfo.printdate: 1789, 1794 Objects 1-31 were printed in 1789; Objects 32-48were printed in 1794.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.4 x 7.9 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.numberleaves: 34Objects 4/5 through 30/31 (that is, all but the first three *Songs of Innocence* objects) are printed recto/verso; all others are printed on rectos only.
objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with color printing on the *Songs of Experience* plates (Objects 32-48) and hand-coloring on all objects
objinfo.printingstyle: relief, with color printing on the *Songs of Experience* plates (Objects (32-48)
objinfo.inkcolor: green (Objects 1-31); green, yellow ochre, blue, and Indian red (Objects 32-48)

objinfo.pennednumbers: none by BlakeThe leaves have been foliated by another hand on rectos (except for the fourteenth leaf, numbered on the verso), 1-17 (in pencil) and 18-34 (in ink).

Gannon in 1947 to Paul Mellon for $13,200; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British Art in 1978.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, the front one gowned and seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude(?) figure; (3) a standing figure, looking down and possibly with a bird flying overhead; (4) an indistinct figure; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves, above and below; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body; (7) a solitary gowned standing figure with two or three flying birds; (8) possibly a seated figure with prominent knees drawn up. lg.l: On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb;
So I piped with merry chear,
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear,
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed.
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle: The Shepherd., Object 4 (Bentley 5, Erdman 5, Keynes 5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks forward and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hilltop in the background, where the pink tints above the horizon suggest that the time is sunrise or sunset. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the light. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird; two even smaller birds perch on the limb below and to the right of those in flight. Dark shadows cover the ground, particularly lower left.

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot,
From the morn to the evening he strays:
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call.
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace.
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle: The Little Black Boy, Object 5 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 2, 6) and "Little Black Boy" (title [line 1]) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. (A twining vine, more fully developed in other copies, protrudes as a half-circle on the right side of the tree trunk.) A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 10) mounts above the horizon in a cloudless sky delicately tinted with pink and yellow.

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me.
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun! there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning. joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space.
That we may learn to bear the beams of love.
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

desc.objtitle: , Object 6 (Bentley 10, Erdman 10, Keynes 10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous plate. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank. Two nude boys—both white or pink in this copy—stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 6) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous plate though not dark-skinned as he was there (presumably in conformation with the sense of "When I from black and he from white cloud free," line 7), stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 11). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. Its roots are partially exposed on the bank to the right. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy. Although colored black in this copy, wavy lines suggest a river running at the foot of the plate. A dark shadow falls across the bank, lower right. Intertwined vines, one bearing leaves or flowers, twist up the lower left margin. One or two vines rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grow up the right margin. The willow-like tree is backed by indeterminate plants or trees. The purple-pink tint in the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care,
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me.
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair,
And be like him and he will then love me.

desc.objtitle: On Anothers SorrowOn Anothers Sorrow, Object 7 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 3, 6, and 12. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers" (line 1), which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left. There may be a second figure climbing in the branches above, opposite stanza 7, although in this copy the figure is indistinct and tends to merge with the vegetation. A third figure with arms raised stands opposite stanzas 2 and 3, although the figure here again merges with the tendrils in this copy. A fourth human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised.

component.illusobjdesc: There may be as many as four figures in the left margin, although only two are clearly pictured in this copy. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. There may be a second figure climbing in the branches above, opposite stanza 7, although in this copy the form tends to merge with adjacent vegetation. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, raises his arms as if in supplication—although here again the figure is hard to separate from the vines in this copy. lg.l: And not be in sorrow too.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child.
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
And not sit the cradle near
And not sit both night & day,
O! no never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not. thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tear,
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young,
And my father sold me while yet my tongue,
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre. who cried when his head.
That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd, so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare.
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair.
And so he was quiet. & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick, Joe Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key.
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free.
Then down a green plain leaping laughing they rThe "r" at the end of line 17 may be the first letter of "run". Lacking sufficient space for the word, Blake etched it above line 17 (line 16).
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind.
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy.
He'd have God for his father & never want joy.
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm.
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
The little ones spend the day.
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour,
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,

And laughing is heard on the hill,

And every thing else is still

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm:

With her left arm at her side, her right arm, which holds the racquet, is raised vertically, and she looks up toward the shuttlecock. She strides forward left foot first, right leg extended backward and her right foot visible.

The handling of barren trees, sky, and clouds integrates the elements of the plate into a single design. Two trees, both leafless, frame the design. The lower branches of the tree on the right arch over two figures underneath. The green tinting of the ground beneath the figures and the background hill suggests grass.

Two hills rise in the background to form the horizon. The handling of barren trees, sky, and clouds integrates the elements of the plate into a single design. Dark sky and clouds are visible above the hill in the background. The nurse, particularly, is framed by the lowering cloud (mustard yellow in this copy) behind her.
